https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/69804/ : SUCCESS
I think we should add `else` and record the error.
we typically don't use the Conditional ternary operator in bmcweb

I think we should do a mapper call first to get the Service and Paths.

E.g. https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43761
The user passed in a wrong value.. message::propertyValueNotInList ?

I think we should do a mapper call first to get the Service and Paths.

E.g. https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/44044

This is the only values supported in the schema 

            "enum": [
                "Never",
                "AnyFault"
            ],
Makes sense.

should we do this check before the GetSubTree?
See that comment on  https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/43761/11/redfish-core/lib/systems.hpp for more information
Please abstract this to a method.

This should be an internal error.

If GetSubTree does not find a service name associated with the interface (i.e. xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Settings) then it will return an empty array. This situation will be handled in your code at line 1277. 

If for some reason GetSubTree does throw an error for some other reason, it most likely needs to be an internal error.
+1. If the interface isn't there the code will hit (subtree.size() == 0). Can you remove this comment?
In line 1718, this error has been processed, here is to ensure that you can exit directly when encountering an error, do Ｉ need to mark the error again here?
I don't think so. You handle the error well at line 1716.

Since we start looking at "/", this should be fine. 
If "xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Settings" doesn't exist the next if is hit.
Why not an internal error here?
Can you remove this comment, it doesn't make sense.. If this D-Bus interface isn't on D-bus it will hit             if (subtree.size() == 0)
Was thinking you would just remove this highlighted text but this is fine.
This looks like it's going to fail on systems that don't support this interface?

We start looking at "/",
If "xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Settings" doesn't exist the next if is hit.

Correct.
If "xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Settings" doesn't exist, subtree size will be 0 but an ec isn't returned

> Correct.
> If "xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Settings" doesn't exist, subtree size will be 0 but an ec isn't returned

In the new commit, I think it is necessary to hardcode “xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Settings”

Why would stop on boot be based on the Logging settings api?  Seems kind of odd that's in that namespace?  Shouldn't this be somewhere in the power settings namespace, given that it's a parameter on ComputerSystem?  Considering that we're in the process of enabling multi-host systems, that seems important.

In https://github.com/ibm-openbmc/dev/issues/1068,
discussed inside,
"StopBootOnFault" is mapping busctl set-property xyz.openbmc_project.Settings /xyz/openbmc_project/logging/settings xyz.openbmc_project.Logging.Settings QuiesceOnHwError b true
@Gunnar Mills

I added Andrew to the review since he added the interface. 
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/commit/c271176a57963ad681859c97c7966a11ecd8ec31
Let's avoid pointing at a company fork / company bug tracker (ibm-openbmc) upstream

From my perspective, considering this is being added to the ComputerSystem interface, doesn't this need to be some system path specific property, similar to how Host state and power control are set up?  There are people working through multi-host platforms as we speak, so the "one global to rule them all" type interfaces don't really work here.

The use case for us (and the reason we took this proposal to DMTF) was for our manufacturing team. They have a new server they are building and they want to ensure the server stops booting on any hardware failure found by firmware for that server. So it was meant to be server wide (not per host). Does that mean we should have put this somewhere else in the Redfish API?

nit: can we prefer to return early here, and avoid the validstopBootEnabled variable alltogether.

This line would go to 
return true;

and line 1946 would go to:
return std::nullopt

Also, the final condition would no longer need to be in an else.
This should be property not supported, not resource not found.  The Resource will exist on all systems.

I resubmit them again to restore them back.
Done.

Same here? Why remove these? Lets do that in a separate commit if these really need changed.
Empty line changes make reverting commits harder, makes git blame harder to understand, etc.

I resubmit them again to restore them back.
Done.
I'm ok with this being a global now that it can be disabled for multi-host configurations.
CI failure was a clang-format issue. Fixed.
Last patch set just fixed a CI fail.
